Award.AwardTitle: IRFP: The Impact of the Double Tropopause on the Composition of the Upper Troposphere and Lower Stratosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad.

This award will support a twelve-month research fellowship by Dr. Tanya R. Peevey to work with Dr. Paul Konopka at Forschungszentrum Jülich in Jülich, Germany.

Multiple stable layers, usually called a double tropopause, are seen in the vertical structure of the Earth's atmosphere within the upper troposphere lower stratosphere (UTLS) region. The UTLS is a key region of the Earth's atmosphere since it contains various radiatively important species, e.g. water vapor, ozone and aerosols, which have been perturbed over time due to less long-wave radiation escaping from the Earth surface as other green house gases (GHGs) increase. The double tropopause forms most frequently in the mid-latitudes and has been associated with an exchange of air masses between the UT and LS. Air mass exchange events can change the local radiative balance by adjusting the local temperature profile and the static stability of the region, which in turn can change the structure of the atmosphere and result in a poleward shift the midlatitude storm tracks for example. Evaluating the impact of double tropopause related transport on the distribution and redistribution of radiatively important species in the UTLS region is important for understanding and predicting the Earth's radiation budget and, consequently, climate and climate change.

This research project will study the UTLS region of the Earth's atmosphere using a unique combination of satellite observations from the High Resolution Dynamic Limb Sounder (HIRDLS), an instrument on the NASA Aura satellite, and model simulations from the Chemistry Lagrangian Model of the Stratosphere (CLaMS), developed at Forschungszentrum Jülich in Germany. The first objective of this project is to establish where air within the double tropopause originates since it could change the composition of the UTLS and thus Earth's radiative budget. The second objective is to understand the relationship between the double tropopause and tropopause inversion layer (TIL), a relationship recently put forth by other scientists using a dry-atmosphere model. That study found that the double tropopause could not form without the TIL being present. This connection is unexpected since these two atmospheric features have opposite spatial preferences and seasonal cycles, thus observations with high vertical resolution and a model specialized for the UTLS will be used to explore this relationship.

Another benefit of this project, in addition to an increased understanding of the UTLS region and Earth's climate, includes the exchange of expertise between the PI and the host institution in Germany. Dr. Peevey will benefit greatly from the exchange by gaining knowledge of lagrangian models and skills in running model simulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Upper Troposphere Lower Stratosphere (UTLS) is a region of the atmosphere that spans the free troposphere into the lower stratosphere. The troposphere begins at the Earth’s surface and ends anywhere between 10 and 17 km in altitude depending upon geographical location; and is thus the lowest portion of the Earth’s atmosphere and contains Earth’s weather systems. It is bounded above by the tropopause, a boundary that distinguishes the troposphere from the layer above, the stratosphere. The tropopause has a break at the subtropical jet (fast winds in the upper troposphere). At this break the tropopause can overlap such that there are two tropopauses (e.g., one at 10 km and at 15 km), forming what is called a double tropopause, the focus of the study.

The double tropopause is an interesting feature in the UTLS because within that structure a exchange of air masses, from troposphere to stratosphere, has been shown to occur under certain conditions. When air masses are exchanged the chemical composition of the UTLS can change, which can impact tropospheric temperatures. Thus, this region is important because it plays a large part in the Earth’s radiation budget, Earth’s present and future climate. Currently the exact composition of the air within the double tropopause is in question. This is important because air that is more tropospheric would imply that it contains high concentrations of water vapor that could change the radiative properties of the lower stratosphere, a relatively dry region of the atmosphere. Therefore, understanding where air within the double tropopause originates is important for the UTLS scientific community along with the public and policy makers due to its strategic importance for understanding and accurately predicting climate change.

Two main results have been drawn from the analysis of the double tropopause, one more technical in nature and one more an expansion of our current understanding of processes that connect the stratosphere and the troposphere. The primary data sets used in this investigation were the High Resolution Dynamics Limb Sounder (HIRDLS), a NASA satellite instrument, and the Chemistry Lagrangian Model of the Stratosphere (CLaMS), a German Lagrangian model. To evaluate the integration of the HIRDLS data set into the CLaMS model, CLaMS was also initialized with data from the Microwave Limb Sounder (MLS). All four data sets were seasonally averaged and then compared to each other. Results showed that CLaMS effectively integrated the HIRDLS data set, but concentrations of ozone and water vapor within the HIRDLS data set had many outliers (data point well beyond expected value) in the upper tropical troposphere when compared to MLS. No effective methods were found to counteract this, thus a seasonal analysis was impractical. In the end a case study approach (looking at individual events) was taken for the remainder of the project. This result highlights the technical limitations of the HIRDLS data set, but also displays its benefits when looking at individual events.

The second result from this study highlights an incremental advancement within the atmospheric science field. After the four data sets (as described above) were analyzed the growth and development of a midlatitude cyclone over the Pacific Ocean was examined as a case study over a four day period, 14-17 January 2006, using observational (HIRDLS) and model (CLaMS) data. This specific phenomenon was chosen since it can be associated with air mass exchange and is spatially coincident with regions containing a high frequency of double tropopauses.
